title: 112_hr6427
content: The Act may be cited as the "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" and includes a Job Training Resources Grant Program. The "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" includes a Job Training Resources Grant Program that provides funds for grants to support job training programs through real property purchase, renovation, construction, or lease. The "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" includes a Job Training Resources Grant Program that provides funds for job training programs for individuals with employment challenges. A qualified self-sustaining job program offers job training, placement, and employment services. The Job Training Resources Grant Program provides funds for job training programs for individuals with employment challenges. It does not require Federal funds for programmatic or administrative expenses, except for specific purposes. Applicants can still participate in other Federal programs. The Job Training Resources Grant Program prioritizes eligible applicants with successful experience in establishing self-sustaining job programs. The Job Training Resources Grant Program prioritizes eligible applicants with successful experience in establishing self-sustaining job programs, including national organizations that have been awarded grants under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The term 'eligible applicant' refers to a national organization, a State or political subdivision, or an Indian tribe or tribal organization, all focused on providing employment-related services to individuals with employment challenges. The curr_chunk discusses grant conditions and requirements for job placement performance goals under a grant awarded by the Secretary to eligible applicants. The Secretary, in coordination with the grantee, must establish job placement performance goals for each qualified self-sustaining job program receiving grant funds, along with performance assessment dates not earlier than 1 year after. The Secretary and grantee must establish job placement performance goals for self-sustaining job programs receiving grant funds, with assessment dates not earlier than 1 year after. Protection of federal interest is required for all real property purchased, renovated, constructed, or improved using funds. The Secretary must ensure the protection of the Federal Government's interest in real property purchased, renovated, constructed, or improved using grant funds. Eligible applicants receiving subawards must comply with the requirements. Out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, funds made available under this paragraph shall be distributed among local member organizations for self-sustaining job programs. Out of $200,000,000 appropriated for grants for self-sustaining job programs, a penalty is imposed for failure to meet job placement requirements. A penalty is imposed for failure to meet job placement requirements in self-sustaining job programs funded through fiscal year 2016. If a recipient of funds fails to meet job placement goals, repayment to the Treasury is required over a 10-year period starting from the date of failure. If a recipient of funds fails to meet job placement goals, repayment to the Treasury is required over a 10-year period starting from the date of failure. The payments must be made without accruing interest, or the recipient may choose to comply with job placement performance with the Secretary's consent. With the Secretary's consent, recipients of funds can choose to comply with job placement goals instead of making payments for non-compliance. Compliance must be demonstrated as prescribed by the Secretary. States facing penalties can also opt for compliance in place of payments. The Secretary may prescribe penalties for non-compliance by states, allowing for a reduction in grants over a 10-year period instead of payments. State penalty limitations do not apply in this case.
